citations.narrative:
The licensee has one male chinchilla. At the time of inspection, the chinchilla was not on site. The licensee stated that the
chinchilla was temporarily visiting a friend’s home. The licensee did not have any disposition records demonstrating the
temporary removal of the chinchilla. Acquisition and disposition records are necessary to be able to accurately track
animals being used in regulated activities to ensure their legal acquisition, proper care, humane transportation, and to be
able to track and trace animals in the case of an animal disease outbreak. The exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain
records or forms which fully and correctly disclose information concerning animals purchased or otherwise acquired,
owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his possession or under his control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or
otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his
possession or under his control. All information found within section 2.75(b)(1) should be recorded, maintained, and made
available for inspection.
To be corrected from this day forward

The licensee had two rabbits in an enclosure lined with mulch. The mulch was excessively wet and dark in color with a
layer of liquid present. The rabbits’ feet and hindquarters were wet and stained. Failure to maintain an enclosure that
keeps the animals dry and clean can lead to unnecessary discomfort and possible disease. All primary enclosures for
rabbits shall be constructed and maintained so as to enable the rabbits to remain dry and clean.
To be corrected from this day forward

On September 3rd, 2023 between the hours of 4-7:30pm, the licensee’s spider monkey escaped from his indoor primary
enclosure and the facility in which the primary enclosure was located. The animal was loose in the community for
approximately 24 hours, before being captured at approximately 7pm on September 4th, 2023. Failure to have a primary
enclosure which adequately contains the animal can lead unnecessary harm to the animal and the public. Primary
enclosures for nonhuman primates must be constructed and maintained so that they contain the nonhuman primates
securely and prevent accidental opening of the enclosure, including opening by the animal.
To be corrected from this day forward

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility has a singly housed blue-and-gold macaw. The licensee does not have an environmental enrichment program
for this bird. Failure to develop and document an environmental enrichment program for birds can negatively impact their
health and well-being, causing unnecessary psychological distress. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a
species-appropriate plan for environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The
plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in subpart G and
with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals and reference guides. This
plan must be made available to APHIS upon request. The plan must address each category listed in 3.154.
To be corrected by 9/18/2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
CARRIE BONGARD, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The licensee has one male chinchilla. At the time of inspection, the chinchilla was not on site. The licensee stated that the 
chinchilla was temporarily visiting a friend’s home. The licensee did not have any disposition records demonstrating the 
temporary removal of the chinchilla. Acquisition and disposition records are necessary to be able to accurately track 
animals being used in regulated activities to ensure their legal acquisition, proper care, humane transportation, and to be 
able to track and trace animals in the case of an animal disease outbreak. The exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain 
records or forms which fully and correctly disclose information concerning animals purchased or otherwise acquired, 
owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his possession or under his control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or 
otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his 
possession or under his control. All information found within section 2.75(b)(1) should be recorded, maintained, and made 
available for inspection.

3.53(a)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The licensee had two rabbits in an enclosure lined with mulch. The mulch was excessively wet and dark in color with a

To be corrected from this day forward 
3.80(a)(2)(iii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
On September 3rd, 2023 between the hours of 4-7:30pm, the licensee’s spider monkey escaped from his indoor primary 
enclosure and the facility in which the primary enclosure was located. The animal was loose in the community for 
approximately 24 hours, before being captured at approximately 7pm on September 4th, 2023. Failure to have a primary 
enclosure which adequately contains the animal can lead unnecessary harm to the animal and the public. Primary 
enclosures for nonhuman primates must be constructed and maintained so that they contain the nonhuman primates

securely and prevent accidental opening of the enclosure, including opening by the animal. 
To be corrected from this day forward 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility has a singly housed blue-and-gold macaw. The licensee does not have an environmental enrichment program 
for this bird. Failure to develop and document an environmental enrichment program for birds can negatively impact their 
health and well-being, causing unnecessary psychological distress. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a 
species-appropriate plan for environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The

with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals and reference guides. This 
plan must be made available to APHIS upon request. The plan must address each category listed in 3.154.  
To be corrected by 9/18/2023
